column3: is the state capital of Kedah
column4: Malaysia. It is the second-largest city in the state after Sungai Petani and one of the most-important cities on the west coast of Peninsular Malaysia. It sits along the country's longest expressway
column5: located 400 km (250 mi) from Kuala Lumpur and 79 km (49 mi) north of George Town
column6: Penang. The city is home to the Central State Administration Centre and is the administrative centre of Kota Setar District.

column1: Its location along the main travel route from Malaysia to Thailand has long made it a major transportation hub in the northern Malay Peninsula. At present
column2: the city covers a land area of 666 km2 (257 sq mi)
column3: which is occupied by more than 300
column4: 000 inhabitants (as per the 2010 census). At the local-government level

column6: interesting places etc. It also become a place of high value property.

column1: Alor Setar is the birthplace of two Malaysian prime ministers
column2: YTM Tunku Abdul Rahman and Tun Dr. Mahathir bin Mohamad.

column1: The name came from the combination of two Malay words: Alor ("small stream") and Setar (Bouea macrophylla Griff.; known as the marian plum
column2: gandaria
column3: or plum mango)
column4: a tree which is related to mango.The city's name was changed to Alor Star during a 21 December 2003 ceremony proclaiming it a city. The city's previous name was restored on 15 January 2009.

column1: Alor Setar was founded in 1735 by Kedah's 19th Ruler
column2: Sultan Muhammad Jiwa Zainal Adilin II and was the state's eighth administrative centre since the establishment of the Kedah Sultanate in 1136. The earlier administrative centres were located in Kota Bukit Meriam
column3: Kota Sungai Emas
column4: Kota Siputeh
column7: Kota Indera Kayangan and Kota Bukit Pinang.

column1: Significant events held in Alor Setar include the returning of Perlis and Setul (now Satun) to Kedah by the Siamese in May 1897 (both provinces had been separated from Kedah in 1821) and a 90-day festival from June to September in 1904 to celebrate the wedding of the five children of Sultan Abdul Hamid Halim Shah.Alor Setar was proclaimed a city – the ninth in Malaysia – on 21 December 2003. A ceremony was held at Dataran Tunku
column2: Alor Setar
column3: attended by the Kedah's Sultan Tuanku Abdul Halim Mu'adzam Shah
column4: his consort Che' Puan Haminah Hamidun

column1: Alor Setar is located in the north-western part of Peninsular Malaysia
column2: at the edge of the Malacca Strait which separates Malaysia from Indonesia. The Kotar Setar district includes Alor Setar
column3: and borders the districts of Kubang Pasu
column4: Pokok Sena and Pendang.

column1: The city encompasses an area of 666 km2 (257 sq mi)
column2: including the neighbouring district of Pokok Sena which falls under the jurisdiction of the Alor Setar City Council. Alor Setar is surrounded by important river systems such as the Kedah River
column3: River Langgar
column4: Tajar River

column1: Alor Setar features a tropical monsoon climate (Am) under the Köppen climate classification. Alor Setar has a very lengthy wet season. As is common in several regions with this climate
column2: precipitation is seen even during the short dry season. Temperatures are relatively consistent throughout the course of the year
column3: with average high temperatures around 32 degrees Celsius and average low temperatures around 23 degrees Celsius. Alor Setar has an average 2
column4: 300 mm (91 in) of annual precipitation.

column1: It is a must ride rivercruise along Kedah river. You get to see Malay villages along the ride and with beautiful and calming scenery. You can take the ride nearby Kedah Museum.
Initially the function of the building was as the Balai Rong Seri or Balai Penghadapan (grand audience hall)
column2: that was situated at the back of the Kota Setar Palace complex (Istana Kota Setar). The original building was built in 1735 by Sultan Muhammad Jiwa Zainal Adilin II
column3: the 19th Sultan of Kedah. The pillars
column4: roofs and floors were made of wood. Two Kedah Sultans were officially installed at the Balai Besar: Sultan Ahmad Tajuddin Halim Shah II in 1805

column1: This 18-metre-tall (59 ft) three-tiered octagonal tower's sole purpose is to house the royal musical instruments including the serunai (wooden flute)
column2: nafiri
column3: gendang (drum) and nobat (gong). The original Balai Nobat
column4: constructed of wood
column5: was among the early buildings already completed when Alor Setar town was officially founded in 1735. It has been rebuilt twice
column6: most recently in 1906 in concrete and metal with a dome representing the Islamic element.

column1: The Tou Mu Kung Temple (Chinese: 斗母宫) is a Taoist temple situated on Jalan Gangsa. Worshipping the Empress Registrar of Birth or Dou Mu and Nine Emperor deities
column2: the temple has both Taoist and Buddhist influences.

column1: Kota Kuala Kedah (a.k.a. Kota Kuala Bahang) is the remains of a fort on the bank of the Kedah River (Sungai Kedah)
column2: which for centuries protected the Kuala Kedah Kingdom from naval attacks.  The fort was originally constructed to provide protection against the Portuguese
column3: and also stood against attacks from the Achenese from Sumatra and the Bugis. The fort was rebuilt in 1771–1780.

column2: Muzium Negeri houses a large collection of Kedah's historical
column3: cultural
column4: and royal heritage. The collection includes early Chinese porcelain
column5: artefacts from the archaeological excavations in Bujang Valley
column6: and a pokok bunga emas or 'gold tree' produced as a tribute to the Thais. The museum is also a research centre which specialises on Kedah's cultural history.

column1: Before the present premises were built in 1936
column2: parts of the museum's collection were on display at the Balai Besar. The museum was officially opened on 3 February 1957.

column1: The Pusat Sains Negara (National Science Centre) is located at Gunung Keriang next to the Alor Setar Aquatic Centre and Paddy Museum. It is the first science centre built in northern Malaysia.
The Muzium Padi is the first paddy museum in Malaysia
column2: and the fourth in the world after Japan
column3: Germany and the Philippines. The museum showcases the rice cultivation process in Malaysia and the tools and equipment used. Murals feature the work of 60 artists from North Korea.

column1: The Kedah State Art Gallery was set up with the objective of fostering interest in and an appreciation of art in the state. Its collection includes paintings
column2: photographs
column3: musical instruments and handicrafts.

column1: The Sultan Abdul Halim Mu'adzam Shah Gallery building originally housed the Alor Setar High Court
column2: before it was moved to Kompleks Mahkamah Alor Setar in Suka Menanti. This building is located at the junction of Jalan Putera
column3: adjacent to the Balai Nobat. This building was built for the existing Balai Seni.

column1: The Kedah Royal Museum had originally been part of the Kota Setar palace. It was rebuilt after attacks by the Bugis (1770) and Siamese (1821). The current concrete building was completed during the reign of Sultan Ahmad Tajuddin Mukarram Shah
column2: who once stayed in this palace with his queen.

column1: This palace is also known as the "Pelamin Palace" after it was extended to include a pavilion and additional rooms
column2: when Sultan Abdul Hamid Halim Shah arranged marriages for his five children. The grand wedding ceremony lasted for three months in 1904. After 1941
column3: the palace was used as a school and an office for several organisations including the office for the St. John Ambulance and the Scout movements. On 25 July 1983
column4: the palace was declared the Kedah Royal Museum.

column1: Pekan Rabu is located near the city's government offices. Although the name literally means "Wednesday Market"
column2: this market is open all week long. It sells a variety of handicrafts and is a popular spot for tourists and locals.

column1: Located in the heart of Alor Setar
column2: this 165.5-metre-tall (543 ft) tower is a prominent modern landmark that signifies the rapid development in Kedah. It serves as a telecommunications tower and tourist attraction
column3: offering a panoramic view of the city and surroundings.

column1: Wan Mat Saman Aqueduct is the longest aqueduct in Malaysia. It connects Kedah River in Alor Setar to Gurun at the south
column2: and was built to boost the state's rice production.

column1: Independence House is a designated historic building which houses the collection and memorial of Tunku Abdul Rahman

column1: The Kedah royal mausoleum is located in Langgar
column2: near the city centre.

column1: Anak Bukit is the birthplace and royal palace of Sultan Tuanku Abdul Halim Muadzam Shah and of the current ruler
column2: Sultan Sallehuddin. Sungai Anak Bukit which is situated behind the royal palace
column3: flows through Alor Setar and is connected by the Kedah River to Kuala Kedah. Since 2008
column4: it has been used in royal ceremonies
column6: and is the very palace were Sultan Sallehuddin was officially enthroned and installed.

column1: Zahir Mosque (Masjid Zahir) is the state mosque of Kedah and enjoys a royal history and patronage. Built in 1912
column2: its official opening ceremony was held on 15 October 1915 by the late Sultan Abdul Hamid Halim Shah. The architecture of the mosque was inspired by the Azizi Mosque in Tanjung Pura
column3: Langkat Sultanate (present-day North Sumatra).

column1: Wat Nikrodharam is a significant Buddhist shrine in the city. It is located at Jalan Teluk Wan Jah
column2: next to the city's primary roundabout. Its architecture reflects strong Thai elements with minor Chinese motifs. It offers a quiet oasis in the city centre. Both Theravada and Mahayana Buddhist traditions are observed here.

column1: Alor Setar has many sport facilities that are open to the public.

Darulaman Stadium is located in Jalan Stadium and Lebuhraya Darul Aman. It is used mostly for football matches and is the official stadium for Malaysian Super League's club Kedah FA. The stadium was built in 1967 and has a capacity of 32
column2: 387 following expansion in 1997. It was one of the venues for the 1997 FIFA World Youth Championship.

column1: Kedah hosted the Sukma Games in 2006.
The capital of Kedah is connected to all parts of Peninsular Malaysia by all transport modes.

column2: which extends from Bukit Kayu Hitam (Malaysia–Thai border town) to Singapore
column3: has made it easy to drive to Kedah. It is a 6–7-hour drive from Kuala Lumpur and 1.5-hour drive from Penang via expressway.

column1: Alor Setar is approached from the east coast via East–West Highway (Lebuhraya Timur Barat). Towns such as Butterworth and Kangar etc.
column2: can also be accessed from Alor Setar. Car rental services are available.

column1: Most of bus companies in Peninsular Malaysia provide air-conditioned express bus services. Tickets can be bought at bus terminals or ticket offices. All buses that arrive in Alor Setar stop at Shahab Perdana Terminal Bus. Those who wish to travel to other towns
column2: including Thailand
column3: can board their bus at this terminal. Local bus services are also available
column4: serving almost all towns in Kedah.

column1: Train services are provided by Keretapi Tanah Melayu Berhad (KTMB) through their ETS services. Train are available between Alor Setar and Kuala Lumpur
column2: Butterworth
column3: Padang Besar
column4: and Gemas. The city' two railway stations are Alor Setar railway station and Anak Bukit railway station. Tickets can be obtained from the train station or online booking.

column1: The Sultan Abdul Halim Airport (Alor Setar Airport
column2: IATA code: AOR) is located at Kepala Batas
column3: 15 km (9.3 mi) north of the city. It serves mostly domestic flights. Malaysia Airlines
column4: Firefly
column6: and AirAsia fly daily to and from Alor Setar and Kuala Lumpur. Since 9 September 2013

column1: Passenger ferry services to and from Langkawi to Kuah Ferry Service are provided at Jeti Kuala Kedah
